Would just like to thank your staff at Milton  Cambridge. Yesterday my niece (8 on Tues) shut the car door on her thumb just before we entered the store. Hello Tescos  I m wondering if you could shed some light on something . I am a mother of a multiple allergy child and I have been purchasing Bfree bread from your stores for some time as that is the ONLY bread my wheat egg dairy soya free child can eat. Sometimes when I try to buy It the bread is out of stock but recently I haven t seen it at all  no ticket etc. last night I spoke to a duty manager from your Toton branch who couldn t really give me a straight answer to wether you still sell it or not but did mention they are having a brand reset which is where you get rid of the brands that don t sell well. So I ask you -  How can you get rid of a brand that is mostly out of stock because it doesn t sell well?  Why if you have gotten rid of the brand are you still selling the wraps? If you are no longer selling this brand are you looking to stock an alternative?  Being an allergy mum is bad enough without supermarkets changing things with no notice!!!  I can t wait to hear from you. Thanks X

Still disgusted at your continued mis-selling of the Graco Milestone car seat I noticed today that you are also quoting incorrect weight limits for the 5 point harness on the  Kids Embrace  line of 1/2/3 car seats. Since these seats only meet the basic safety requirements to be used as intended the consequences of using them past the approved limits could be fatal. So  I used the Direct service for a preorder on Uncharted 4. I put the order in a year ago  and just moved house. No problem you might think  the game has been delayed for another month  just change the address. Not so...  On enquiring about this I was told  essentially   Computer says no.....  and that they couldn t change the delivery address for whatever reason. Their ONLY suggestion? Cancel there order and replace it.   Ah  says I  that s a bit awkward as I placed the order via a special offer  and used Clubcard points to do it. I don t think you d be refunding me the value of the game so that I could simply reorder it? Or do you have any other suggestions or solutions? Could you change it to click and collect?  Nope. Only suggestion is to cancel. No options. No suggestions. No help. No customer care. Just cancel. I pushed a little  and subsequently was replied to by someone who called me by your staff members name ( Dianne? Really?) And then when i requested the issue was treated as a complaint  I was essentially told that the onus was on me to ensure that I PAID for a redirection  despite the fact that I was giving you a month s notice to change the address.   To call the service poor is an understatement. To say I m annoyed  even more so.   Sort yourself out Tesco  and possibly employ Customer service people with a) initiative and b) Customer Service skills.

Hi Tesco. I like a good Pick n Mix  it has to be said. Some days I think  ...know what would just top this day off?! A cardboard cup of sugary goodness to dip my sweaty little digits in  and pull out the golden nectar; a fried egg . That s how much I like a Pick n Mix.   This afternoon  after spending around 2 hours in the garden  going back and forth with the mower  I thought  ...know what would just top this day off!? A cardbo...  you get the drift...  So  as excited as Phil Mitchell at happy hour in the Queen Vic  I dove into my motorised vehicle and made my way to your store  gleefully hopped in the door and grinned at the wondrous selection on offer to tempt my tastebuds. I made my choice  mouth watering and all  took it to the till (self service  5p for a bag an  that) and made my way home to devour each and every sugary lump of glory...  ...first out: A FRIED EGG!!! CAN YOU BELIEVE IT!?! This was just too exciting. I waited patiently as I held it between my fingers and took in the moment. With that  I threw it in and couldn t wait for the taste sensation to tickle my tastebuds...  Hard. Rock Solid. I like Pick n Mix  but I also like my teeth...I d rather they weren t smashed into bits at the mercy of a single fried egg. This batch seems to be a little  overcooked   Tesco and it has simply not topped this day off. The bananas weren t any better.   Yours Pick n Mixingly  Craig üç≥  P.S the Cola Bottles were fine  so good job on that.

Not happy! Today we did our weekly tesco shop at tesco arena Coventry.At the entrance was a candy crush advertising team with two people dressed in shapes (faces Covered) when we entered one of the mascots were waving at our four year old daughter and she wanted to go back to see them at the end of our shopping trip.so as my partner was loading the shopping onto the belt I took my daughter to go and see the candy crush mascots.i stood a few steps back so she could go and say hello.she approached one and showed him/her the teddy she was holding.they took it from her hand and threw it across the floor I mean not just drop it but literally threw it  3 metres away! I m still in shock now that they have done this! A man and lady who were also there advertising saw the teddy on the floor and saw my daughter upset.they asked if it was my daughter or him that had thrown the teddy to which I replied him! They didn t apologise for having such an idiot of a colleague just shook there head.my 4 year old daughter came away upset which is quite understandable after this idiot of a person did this! All she wanted was a simple high five and hug but instead was face to face with a complete and utter imbecile.I m not one to make a scene but really wish I had now and got them to apologise face to face to my daughter.disgusting behaviour for anyone that is trying to sell a product to the public!  very unprofessional and obviously a child themselves thinking this is fun to do to a four year old little girl.

dear tesco   i am amazed and totally gob smacked as to what i have just seen in my local tesco store number 2253 catford  at 14.53pm as i had just finished paying for my shopping the fire alarm was activated  what happened next did amaze me  most of the staff on the tills got out there seats and made to the exit  which is understandable butas i got to the exit the security guard was still letting people into the store and the staff were walking out of the door in there droves. i decided to stand to watch how the staff handled the situation  (i was a trained fire marshal in my last job). i stood there for around two minutes where i saw more and more staff coming out of the main doors not even stopping people going into the store  from where i was stood i could see that there were still plenty of customers in the store still happly walking around doing there shopping with no one asking them to leave as most of the staff had left the store by this time  deciding i had seen enough i walked around the corner to where the staff enter the store to my amazement again there must have been at least 15 staff all stood there laughing and joking and smoking with no regard to the customers in the store that were still left in there. does the store staff have any training or protocol in store for a fire evacuation of the complete store  including customers or are they just told to leave the store.???  i am in total shock as to how the situation as handled by the staff at the store. 

Oi tesco  I have a bone to pick with you! I m from Oxfordshire and my local store is in Bicester! The past few weeks I ve been travelling to the store on a Sunday to purchase my favourite nuts (salt and black pepper cashews) so I can enjoy them while I watch the football but I ve been bitterly disappointed. Understandable because you guys are changing stores!  Anyway. Today  I ve finished work early (cheeky half day on a Friday) so I thought I d travel to my new local store that opened yesterday! I was excited to see what you guys had to offer! And what a superb job you guys have done. Pat yourselves on the back you deserve it!!  But  my trip to tesco today has turned into a tragic and distraught experience for me (and my girlfriend who I ve been venting my anger and disappointment to for the past half hour). I think by now you know what s coming...  So  I walk down the aisle where various crisps  nuts and other snacky items were. I find myself staring into what I can only describe as  nut hell  trying to locate the salt and black pepper cashews  that were the soul purpose of the trip. Nothing! Couldn t find them anywhere! Can you understand why I m so distraught?  Could you please shed some light on this please! I ve been forced to by normal salted cashews. It s not on tesco!   Regards  Lewy heath

So angry to say the least. Left my bank card in tescos not even 24hrs ago & it s now been destroyed. It took 5 different people in total to help today  some telling me a load of rubbish about not been able to get it until later as it would set of an alarm. Half an hour later I get told it s at the police station  they keep some lost cards but not all. 30 minutes to check for a card! Went to the police station to find out it has been destroyed. Such a joke! Left with no bank card now because tesco seem like they don t have any proper processes in order for these kind of things. A simple message isn t even passed on to the store to ensure it is still there for me. Did not expect this to happen with a massive business chain like this.

Just wanted to say how over weld we are by the service we received from your delivery staff this morning. A need to say a massive shout out to tesco extra in Kilmarnock  while shopping yesterday  my little boy had a freak accident and fell out the trolley ..... Blood curdling crunch  .... The full of tesco came to a complete stand still  and every one  myself included were in slow motion ..... My son had completely knocked himself unconscious  in my panic  of course my instinct was to lift him and cuddle him  he came round and was violently sick twice  while all the time the staff were amazing  and never once made me feel stressed or panic  there kindness and empathy  was exactly what I needed to keep myself calm and also him ... I would like to thank the nice lady who invited my autistic son in to look around the community room at Altrincham Tesco this morning. To the Tesco delivery man who delivered to my Grandparents house    Let me start by saying a smile costs nothing  you should try it. You were very rude upon entering their home I witnessed as I was there with my partner and one year old daughter. It has since come to my attention that when you left you saw fit to take your concerns to the staff room where a friend of ours actually works as a delivery driver too (small world ey?). So let me clear up a few things for you...   The reason it says on our notes at home that we would like the shopping delivered to the kitchen and not the front door is because my Nana is disabled (not my Grandad who answered the door and had  nothing wrong with him ) although my Grandad did actually have a stroke the year before last. Which was actually a horrible experience  we nearly lost him and his left arm doesn t work anymore. He still gets our names confused sometimes and his memory isn t what it was. I digress  my Nana has a blue badge due to her countless illnesses  she has diabetes and nerve damage to her feet which leaves her in constant pain. She stays in bed most days and has to use a wheelchair when she does go out as she has crippling arthritis. This is the least of her worries really as the nerve damage in her back and neck has left her with two major surgeries  constant pain and damage to her voice box. So I m sorry you had to walk our shopping into the kitchen rather than the door  is that disabled enough for you?  My partner actually tried to help but when you barged through and nearly nocked over my Nana and daughter he thought it best to keep them out of the way. I don t know if you ve ever looked after a one year old but you are welcome to come and test it out of you think it constitutes as  sweet F A .   I hope this clears some issues up for you.   Regards    Cassie

Dear Tesco  Today I recieved some pretty horrific customer service from an optician in your Bishop Auckland store. When I arrived it was a frantic atmosphere  I was soon told by one of the assistants that yesterday their manager took ill and had to have his/her appendix removed  (I didn t catch if it was a man or woman)  so that explained the rush. The lady who arranged my appointment who was truly wonderful  a credit to your store  squashed me in that afternoon and took a pre test straight away so it was even quicker for me. When I returned the same lady greeted me  she talked me through the different frames you offer and again she was great. Then the optician called me through  from the moment I sat down he did not seem to have the time of day for me  I explained what I needed my glasses for and how I had been having migranes recently  but I furthur explained how I had been working a lot more and tried to make light of things with little jokes  which were not well recieved. During the appointment he was very rushed and seemed to be accusing me of faking eye-sight problems. He was changing lens  asking me if I could see a difference when I was answering honestlty he kept asking me if I was sure  and then the icing on his rude cake he said the line a health professional should never say   Are you sure  because we all love to say yes.  Overall he made me feel as though he did not have time for me  he did not want to help me  and he did not belive that I needed my glasses  (which I have been recieving on prescription from Tesco for 4 years). Sadly he was not wearing a name badge  lucky for him as I would most certainly name drop. I bought my glasses as I was in a rush  but I will not be visiting your opticians again.

I would like to register my dissatisfaction with the customer service we have received from Tesco following damage to our property when a Tesco delivery driver delivered our shopping 3 weeks ago.  The driver accidentally snapped off the waste pipe that leads from our bathroom to the outside drain.  I appreciate that accidents happen and anticipated that Tesco would work quickly to agree a plan for fixing the damage caused.  However  despite phone calls by my husband chasing a resolution we have been passed from pillar to post with none of your managers willing to take responsibility.  On 2 April it was confirmed to us that the matter had been  escalated  to Head Office  but more than a week on  and 3 weeks after the incident we have received no communication from Head Office.  As a loyal Tesco customer spending an average of ¬£500 - ¬£600 in Tesco stores every month I am disgusted with this level of customer service and look forward to hearing from you with a suitable resolution to this situation.

In life it seems so often that we are quick to moan  by letter  WhatsApp  Email or when talking on the phone. Well today I m goint to change that  I m not going to give you strife  you see your toothpaste has transformed me  given me a better life. My teeth they were so sensitive  whether tepid  hot or cold  so I would wince and cringe and cry  my language sometimes bold! The pain it would be awful  my diet choices changed  no ice creams  lollies or sorbets  it s a wonder I m not deranged. So I set myself a challenge  a cure I d surely find  must be a solution somewhere  that solution I would find. I travelled up and down the aisles of many a chemist shop  The well known brands were expensive  it would cost me lots of money to make to problem stop. Then one day whilst out shopping  I spied your very own brand. I picked it up and did a jig  the price it was not grand. I brought it home excitedly and put in on the shelf  to sort my teeth and be pain free would not affect my wealth. The weeks have passed  the pain has gone  I really do feel jolly  until this point I d never known how much a loved a lolly! So I want to say a big thank you from the bottom of my heart  from the scientists to the shelf fillers  you all have played your part. Your toothpaste is amazing  a mini miracle in a box. Thank you Tesco  thank you! Your supermarket rocks!

Tonight Tesco  I had a very stressful experience. I decided rather than Take my two older children shopping in the day (as it s half term) I would just take our new nine week old baby girl instead  in the evening. So after lots of feeding and a clean nappy ...off we went.  However once in my local Chorley store my little bundle proceeded to cry the whole way around the shop  now with quite a list and two weeks of Half term this shop needed to be done. So I stopped in the stores feeding room and fed the baby. This pattern continued for 45 min with me getting quite flustered and trying to steer a heavy trolley and bounce an unsettled baby at the same time. Then Tesco your lovely staff came to my rescue....like a beacon of light in the dark they helped me with my shopping. First I had a lovely lady who whilst I went and fed the baby took my list and trolley and finished off most of my shopping. I then had two lovely ladies at the till who helped me pack and load my trolley and reassure me that all was ok. They didn t make me feel awkward  they just chatted calmly despite my crying infant and cooed over how lovely she was. This in turn made me relax slightly (despite the fact I was frazzled). And as I left another lovely lady came and offered to help me to the car. She then unloaded my bags into the boot and put away the trolley.  Tesco to you this may seem like those ladies where just doing their job. But tonight they all went above and beyond and showed so Much kindness. My little girl was born early and looks like a new born  I am  feeding her myself and despite all best plans tonight she just wanted me to feed her more. I was able to do this and finish my shopping thanks to the wonderful staff in this store. I am eternally grateful and really think they should be recognised for their good work and help. Tonight Tesco every little really did help and these ladies are superstars!! üòä

There are 1 million people who suffer with Dementia in the UK  and my Nanny is one of them. Its a heartbreaking disease  and I m sure many of you have known or loved someone who has it. There are a lot of similarities between a small child and a dementia sufferer  my Nannys new little quirks brought on by her disease often make me smile and laugh  its become her. I need to tell you about yesterday and how i almost lost that smile.  I went to meet my Mum and Nanny in Tesco Yeovil for a coffee and a catch up. Now like many Dementia sufferers my Nanny has sought comfort in a Doll  a toy for many children  comfort for my Nanny. She likes to bring the doll with her everywhere. Something I m proud that my family has no issues or embarrassment doing. The doll gives her lots of joy and comfort  but not just for her  for myself and family also  since loosing her beloved Husband  its means she not alone when she goes to sleep or when she wakes up  she has something to look after  something to mother  someone else to love.  Now when i went to order my coffee in Tesco  I noticed a lady staring at my Nanny  now of course people will look  double take  its different  something most haven t seen before  most go on with there day & don t give it a second thought. This Woman continued to stare  she was with her teenager daughter who told her to stop looking. I waited for my coffee  and sat back down  she continued to turn around  her back was turned to us  so as you can imagine making it extremely obvious she was staring. She then began to laugh  her daughter nervously laughing with her  telling her to stop. Continuing to giggle and stare at my Nanny  at us.  At this point  my whole body was raging  my tummy doing flips  for anyone that knows me  I don t shy away from confrontation  i wanted to run over there and tell her exactly what i thought! I wanted to get my Nanny out of there and protect her. But instead i looked over at her and her doll  smiling  happy enjoying having coffee with her Daughter and Granddaughter  not a care in the world. She didn t notice the rude woman laughing at her  the anger in my face  the upset in my Mums. We did not say a word about the situation to each other  my Mum went for a cigarette and took a time out  i turned my back to the woman and we continued as if nothing had happened. As much as i wanted to run over and scream at her  for my Nanny sake we just laughed and smiled with each other.  So to the Woman who laughed  the woman who stared - I Thank you  because i now know i can deal with the situation i was always dreading  the way it should be dealt with.  I hope you can bring your daughter up a lot better than you were raised. Ive still got my smile.  I wanted to write this  just to raise a little awareness  I ve seen and heard of a lot of dementia suffers  taking comfort in dolls  teddies etc  Please don t be cruel  that could be your loved one  one day.

Hi  I d like to begin this message by saying that this is not an attack on Tesco. My aim is to spread awareness about an issue that has been around for decades.   My girlfriend works at the checkout at Sainsbury s  and has experienced this problem since she started working there a few years ago. The problem I am referring to is customers (particularly men aged 30+) approaching her outside of her working hours.   Of course  part of a shop assistant s job is to be kind to customers and make sure that they are fully satisfied  and so to do this they must smile and make small talk so that customers feel happy and comfortable. However  this behaviour  probably 90% of the time  is mistaken for  flirtation  and consent for the customer to approach the employee if they see them outside of the workplace.   Now I m not talking about a customer passing by an employee in the street just saying  hello!  and moving on. What I m talking about is customers physically stopping employees in the street by grabbing their arm  and then proceeding to talk with the employee for more than 10 minutes  and continuing to talk even after the employee has told them they need to leave. In a lot of cases  some of which I have experienced myself in a retail job  customers even ask employees for their phone number.  This is harassment. It may not be sexual or physical  but it is still harassment  and it s an issue that seriously needs to be dealt with. Of course the employee in these kinds of situations has no choice but to be kind and considerate to the customer as their jobs can potentially be at risk if they seem rude in any way  and so the answer could not simply be for the employee to dismiss the customer straight away or politely explain that they do not wish to talk to the customer outside of work. There is always a risk that the customer will react with aggression  or even complain about you to the company that you work for.   My girlfriend suffers from anxiety  but has overcome so much in the past few years. Now she has told me recently that she worries on her walk to work every day that she will bump into a customer and have to put up with this harassment again and again.   Something needs to be done. I don t know what  but this is a problem for customers in workplaces all around the globe. I hope I can at least raise more awareness with this message  and I hope that customers read this and think again about approaching employees outside of their workplace.

I would like to tell you about a truly amazing experience that I had in your store in Basingstoke. My wife and I have been in hospital with my daughter who is unwell. When I left the hospital last night to get some dinner for us both and to pick up some coke my wife called to say that she needs some headphones as the TV sound goes off at 21:00 and she wanted to be able to listen to what she was watching. I went into the store and asked one of your managers who s name was Ben ( I think he is the online manager) where the headphones were in the store. He took me to them and on the way we were talking and I explained about being in hospital with my daughter and what had happened with the TV. He said that I can t imagine what you are going through and the least you want to be worrying about is headphones please have them on us. I was so taken back that Ben had obviously seen I was a little tired and emotional and offered this very kind gesture. It felt like he had given me a million pounds. This goes to show that there are some very kind people out there and I am still overwhelmed with Bens very kind gesture. Please can I ask that this gets shown to the most senior person possible so that Ben gets the most amount of credit as possible. Thank you Tesco for employing people like Ben.

I ve just experienced the most disgusting service I ve possibly ever received from any retailer I ve visited and that s saying something.   Visited your Great Notley store in Braintree late at 11:35 25 minutes before closing as my girlfriend works late and this was the only chance we had to go  just needed a few bits so wouldn t take long.  We proceeded told by several members of staff that the store was due to close shortly which was fine as we expected this. Everything went well until we got to the checkout just after 11.50 with what we thought would be more than enough time to scan our items.  As we were walking to the checkout with a small basket of items the security guard waiting at the self checkout shouted out  doubt you ll be getting that through before we close  which we ignored as we could not tell whether he was joking or not. The customer service assistant at the self checkout sighed as we walked up and then proceeded to almost steal our basket away and rushed our items through the self checkout and then put them on the floor and told us to pack them! In the mean time the security guard was making comments in the back ground that were in no way subtle   for god sake  didn t you know the store closes at 12  this isn t 24 hours today you know  why do customers do this  next time come earlier   this was all right behind us and the assistant at the checkout was just agreeing with the security guard whilst packing our shopping leaving my girlfriend and myself standing there just shocked! The assistant then proceeded to give us instructions to pack our shopping immediately as the store was about to close which we were well aware of then telling my girlfriend to pay quickly  to get her change and receipt before nearly had to hand it to her himself. The security guard behind us was telling customers coming through the door that the store was closed  even though this was before 12 and the doors were still open. One customer got sent out even though she just wanted some bread and milk. If a store is advertised as closing at 12 then why are your employees turning business away if it s not yet closing time? Surely that cannot be commercial? I told both employees that you shouldn t treat customers this way and it is in no way acceptable to do so which they did not reply to. Finally we were escorted to the door quickly which was fine as we couldn t wait to leave at this point. As we left one of your employees who opened the door for us apologised for the service and said I hope you do come back to us and I thanked him for noticing as my girlfriend made them aware next time we wouldn t return.  I cannot understand how you can let your staff act this way and treat customers so badly considering its customers like myself who actually keep your business running. I am a mother of one year old triplets and unfortunately this week we have been plagued with a gastroenteritis virus. We have been using Tesco Ultra Dry nappies and wipes and always been very happy with them. During the last few days  I m sure you wont wish to imagine  they have been well and truly tried and tested. I can t speak highly enough of these products  they have been reliable  kind to my babies bottoms and with the volume we have been through come up trumps cost-wise. Yesterday alone we went through 53 nappies and three packs of wipes. Having tried big name brands previously  as well as competitor supermarkets  your nappies are by far the best I have found and have been a saving grace for a mother surrounded by poo (albeit contained) in her hour of need. We have also noticed the new and improved elastic sides and tabs which have massively reduced accidents and therefore save me hours of floor cleaning and baby clothes soaking. Thank you very much Tesco.

Today me and my two children visited the store  Copdock Ipswich.  Whilst I was impressed by the service I was offered by the mobile phone sale s man  the lady at the money exchange and the car valet service  I m afraid I cannot say the same for my experience in the caf√©. At first all was well. My children enjoyed a sausage and chip lunch whilst I enjoyed a hot coffee. When my elder son  Oscar  finished  he asked if he could have one of the yummy chocolate muffins he had spotted whilst ordering lunch. Now  my younger son had not quite finished so I took this opportunity to give Oscar a bit of  independence  and a little life learning experience. I handed him a ¬£5 note  and said to him   make sure you join the back of the queue  be patient  be poliet . I could see the glee in his face that I  for the first time trusted him to venture a little further by himself and take this step. When he walked nicely over to the counter I positioned myself so I could see both my younger son finishing his lunch  and Oscar  queueing for his muffin. What I saw next I watched in disbelief  and my heart sank. Not one person acknowledged my son who  after waiting patiently was now at the front of the line. Instead I watch customer after customer being served instead. His little smile  turned into frustration  yet he still stood waiting patiently. I walked over  helped him pick his muffin and we went to the till together. It was only then he was acknowledged.  I m writing this because if it had been an adult in that situation it would not be stood for. I am raising my son s to treat ALL people with respect  have manners and patients. Something I feel he demonstrated a lot more than your staff and customers today. Please make your staff aware they should acknowledge EVERYBODY. What if my son was a little boy lost and wanting someone to help him? No one even bothered to ask. As for my son  I m proud that he remained patient and polite. Something I struggled to do after witnessing his puzzled little face as to why no one was looking at him.  As for his little life lesson  not all people are raised with manners.

Hello tesco people.   On Thursday I had a delivery to my house full of wonderful Treats!! Now normally I am very happy to see the men that come to my door to bring me food. . who wouldn t. They are always so polite and play chit chat with my delightfully snotty children.   But this Thursday I was a little annoyed that while bringing the create full of wonderfulness to my door the tesco man knocked a few of my plant pots spilling mud all over my path. . now I have no idea of knowing if this was on purpose or an accident as he was already at the door by the time I saw.   A little annoyed I kept it to myself and stewed about it. More annoyed at myself for being a wimp and not asking him why he didn t just move them or even wait and I would have!!   Then tesco  you wonderful people  send me a text asking me about the service today. Normally it s 2 or 3 texts asking me on a scale how happy was I.  For the first time ever I gave you bottom marks. I know I felt bad but I was hoping to get my pent up annoyance but then you simply reply. oh sorry. . . well not quite but no asking why. . or how. . nothing.   So Now I m taking to passive aggressively leaving a message on here to finally get out my annoyance over my poor muddy path!  Now That feels good to get it out.

I dislike pages (The Asda one  where I originally posted this  so kudos Tesco that I can write here as a new post!) which don t let you write a new post  so I am just going to have my say by tacking a coment on to this (though I bet Asda will delete it) So usually I do my shopping online at Tesco  but this month I thought I would be a dare-devil and try Asda. What can I say.... NEVER AGAIN!!! I usually shop for 2-3 weeks in advance of my delivery date. Five days before my delivery date  I encountered a problem with the search engine (*1* result when I searched for jam!). I reported it  but didn t get a reply from Asda until the day after my delivery. One of their substitutions made no sense - I wanted a jar of tahini and was sent a smoked BBQ rub instead. One of their substitutions was sending me 140g of cashews instead of the 200g I ordered - and still charging me the 200g price! I ordered some organic lemons - thery arrived in a pack with a  best before  date of 9th april. Went to use them on the 8th to find two of them totally mouldy. By now I was totally disillusioned  but the icing on the cake was when I decided to check the expiry dates on the rest of my stuff  only to discover that almost everything fresh was ridiculously short-dated. For example brand products which I have bought from other retailers with around 3 weeks in which to use them - and from Asda  with only around 3-5 days! This has made me believe that Asda must be instructing their employees to pick the shortest-dated stuff for their online customers. I complained  of course  and I got a phone call from a very pleasant customer services lady who sorted out refunds for me - but that s not the point. I don t want to be wasting my time in having to check things and complaining. Which is why I shan t be shopping online ith ASDA again. It s back to Tesco for me!

Dearest Tesco...  I felt I should write to you to explain how my world came crashing down around me  whilst ordering our groceries using your obviously incredible online shopping website thing this afternoon. Grab a tissue  this is an emotional one.  The wife and I have been using your home delivery service for proper ages now  as basically we re too lazy to physically go to the shops  and have never had a problem since. Not even when our ordered meat for a small Sunday roast was substituted with a ¬£12 lamb joint the size of New Zealand. We re committed you see  and normally obstacles that we face on the road to stuffing our fridge  freezer  cupboard or face are instantly dismissed and laughed at heartily  especially where Tesco is concerned.  I openly admit that I wrote to you before regarding the stiff caps on your children s yoghurt pouches  (the ones that gave our daughter forearms like Popeye)  but I swept all that under the carpet. All forgotten.  Now  over the past few months I made a tidy discovery in your store. A legend of the freezer department. A revolution in baked curry dishes. A prime piece of pastry perfection. Yep  that s right  I m talking about your awesome Tesco Chicken Madras Bakes. These awesome treats are not only an example of Michelin star food production  but they also come at the bargain price of 99 english pence per 2 bake box. An absolute bargain. Not sure exactly how you re making profit on them  but who am I to complain.   Up until last weekend I had successfully smashed just over 4 000 individual bakes down my neck  and given their high nutritional value  I ve gained around 3 stone in lean muscle thanks to the raw protein intake supplied by the chunks of quality chicken these bakes provide. I owe you a few knuckle taps for that. I have eaten them all day  every day  at home  work and in bed.  Anyway  earlier today I was browsing said amazing grocery site  excited to order my favourite baked Indian cuisine  but to my horror  it said that you don t sell them anymore.   I know  mental isn t it.   At first I thought this could be some kind of belated April Fool s joke  but I soon realised that s not your style. You re no fools  but then again  you would be to give up on such an amazing invention. If you ve tried them yourself then you re probably as shocked as me. If you haven t  then I really do feel for you.  My freezer  my balanced diet  my mood  my marriage  my job  and my ability to purchase the finest in Madras-based pastry products are all affected by your decision to cull my beloved Chicken Madras Bakes  and I was wondering  aside from explaining the real reason for the axe  if there is anything you can do for me as compensation for such heartache  as I find this situation more upsetting than the end of Marley & Me.  Thanks in advance  and indeed for the now sadly unavailable Tesco Chicken Madras Bakes.  Much love and all that jazz  Dave

Wow!! What amazing customer experience I ve just had at Bradley Stoke Superstore (store no. 5652).  My dad had sadly passed away and had 6 unopened spindles of blank Tesco branded DVDs. He did have to check and he spoke to his manager Paul Waspe who agreed not only for me to be allowed to bring the DVDs back  but for me to be given a full refund!!   I was so taken aback by this amazing offer after leaving the customer service desk....I cried. I was quite emotional anyway as these discs were bought by my dad and I had kind of expected it to be a  no !  This is what you call Customer Service. A BIG thank you to Mohammed and Paul for not  following the usual rules for refunds  and  putting the customer first .

Dear Tesco   I booked to have my grocery delivery between 7pm and 8pm tonight. By 8.30pm it hadn t arrived so I called customer services. A very helpful lady looked into the issue and said the delivery driver had tried and failed to deliver at 7.03pm  and had left a card. I can assure you both my husband and I were in at that time and in fact  I had been in the house all day. The doorbell works and there is a door that can be knocked on too. No card was left nor was any delivery attempted at my house. The customer services lady then contacted the delivery driver on our behalf who said he d try again at the end of his other deliveries and that she d call back at 9.30pm to see if we had received our groceries. At 9.30pm I got my call  from a man at the depot this time  who said they were organising another driver to meet the original one  collect our order and deliver it to us. Great  we thought  only two hours late but at least it s on its way. 10.10pm and we were still waiting for our order so I called the man back to see how things were going. This time I was told they can t deliver and will bring it tomorrow instead.  It is way past my bedtime  Tesco  and I wish this had been the solution originally rather than making me wait up all this time. Would I still be waiting now  had I not made that phone call? Now I sincerely hope  Tesco  that 1) I will not incur another delivery charge  since I understand that is the practice if the customer misses their original delivery slot  as I was actually at home at 7.03pm and 2) my delivery does indeed arrive tomorrow.  Yours faithfully  a tired customer.

Hi  I have sent this through to your customer services email but wanted to post on here  just to make sure the people mentioned get the feedback they deserve. I attended your Pontardawe store around lunch time on Thursday 31st March and would like to say thank you for the great customer service I received. This what happened:- It was my daughter s 5th birthday in 2 days so I had to go shopping for food for her birthday party and had to take my 2 children with me (age 2 and 4 at the time). Shopping with children can be stressful at the best of times  let alone when you have something important like a party to plan for. I had already been to 2 shops previously to visiting your Pontardawe store and had been out of the house with my children for 3 hours already so by this point I was slowly losing my patience and they were understandably bored. My son had started to throw a temper tantrum in the trolley and was screaming  I had a few looks off people judging me  who obviously didn t know the whole story. This wasn t what Peter did instead he asked my son what was the matter. And although my son didn t answer  he immediately stopped crying  which broke the tension. Peter was very friendly and carried on interacting with both of my children and by the time we walked away my children were much happier. At the time I didn t thank Peter as I was very stressed and in my own little world. I then proceeded to the self service checkout while I was scanning my items Gerry was talking to my children and kept them amused while I finished scanning my items. This is when I realised I should have thanked Peter for his earlier intervention. By the time I left your store I was much less stressed and my children were in a better mood too  which is very unusual for a shopping trip with children. People are very quick to complain (myself included) but forget to say thank you for good service. Peter and Gerry provided exceptional customer service and what may not have seemed like a big deal to them made a huge difference to my day!

~Letter of complaint  I am writing to express strong disatisfaction on your services in St. Paul s street Tesco (Shopping centre). I wanted to buy a drink yesterday and I was not allowed to because the assistant considered that I look under 25 and I had to show my ID card. When I did so  she told me that it is not accepted and I had to carry my passport in order to get a bottle of wine!  First and foremost  I have a Tesco club card which confirms my age (24). Secondly  I use my ID card to travel all over the EU  I am a EU citizen and according to the EU legislation I can do so ( Regulation EC No 562/2006). Thirdly  I showed all my student cards (I am a PhD student  which I think proves I am over 18) and my bank cards  via which I order online every time  including alcohol. I think that it is vey unfair that I can order online without showing any passport documents but on the other hand I cannot buy a product on my own in a supermarket. Finally  I also had my EU health card  which has my date of birth on it  as all the previous documents. As you can imagine I was really upset and this is so subjective  as I am living in Ireland for 14 months and never had I such an issue on buying products  including Tesco.   I am really disappointed on this behaviour  which is unjustified. I also complained in the customer service but the problem was not solved. I do not really know what is the solution  but I would really appreciate it if I did not have to argue in the supermarket everytime I need to get a product.  I would appreciate it if you could look into this matter as soon as possible.  Kind regards

I have just been on a late evening visit to Tesco Extra in Hartlepool and wondered if you could clear something up for me? I explained that I need to know whether I need to replace the items on my way home so that I can cook dinner but this didn t help. Still waiting and still have no idea whether I need to buy the food again on my way home. At no point has anyone offered me any sort of compensation for the calls and time out of my day to sort this  or a refund for the missing items or for the delivery  given that I am likely to have to make a special trip to buy these items when the whole point of me paying to get them delivered last night was so that I didn t have to go to the store myself and would have the food in time to cook this evening s dinner.
I purchased some butter from Tesco s  and you tell me it s not butter.  I can t believe that  sorry.

Can you please tell me the allergy advice for a pre cooked standard chicken on your hot deli counter? All they could tell me is that it had a seasoned baste but not what was in it.

Another nappy complaint! I phoned this morning to complain about your Tesco Ultra Dry nappies today and spoke to a lovely girl called  I think  Chantelle.  It is obvious this nappies have changed as they are now thinner and the material is  crispier . The extra stretch on the waist tabs is a good idea but as soon as the nappy gets wet they sag like mad and droop!! The wet area is not evenly spread and hangs between the legs.  However my complaint was about the crystals in the nappy. When my daughter woke from her sleep this morning I changed the nappy she had been in all night and was disgusted to find her bottom was covered in the gel crystals from the nappy!!   I spoke to Chantelle  who was very helpful  and she advised me to take the used nappy  packaging and any unused nappies back to the shop to complete a complaint form. However when I said they were part of my home delivery she had to put me through to the home delivery team.  However Maurice who I then spoke to just wanted to refund me the price of the nappies and couldn t get off the phone quick enough!! I asked him if it would be looked into and he said a message would be sent to the Beverley store where they came from. No bar code or reference number was taken! How can the manufacturer follow up a complaint without these details?  Reading through the comments on this page I see that this is not a one off faulty pack but that the nappies in general are now being made to a lower standard than before! I have always bought your nappies over the Pampers that I have used for my older children as they were genuinely better nappies but I will not be buying them anymore!  I look forward to hearing your comments

I received in the post this morning from Tesco  a pack containing 2 sachets of cesar dog food.  I m wondering who  either at Tesco or Cesar thought it s a good idea to do this ? luckily I was at home  but had I not been  my dog would have certainly eaten them both. Dogs are often on special diets because of health conditions and life threatening allergies  and owners restrict what their dogs consume.  A small dog would almost certainly damage it s mouth chewing through the pouch itself  and if swallowed there could be potentially fatal consequences. Please Tesco  don t do this !

Dear Tesco  I write to you to convey a message of great importance. i hope you will take it to heart and act upon what i have to say.  Over the millennia that humans have inhabited this planet they have manufactured and used tools which help to make various task easier to achieve; be it a tool or weapon to catch prey for food  a specific brush for an artist to produce a beautiful masterpiece or an online social media outlet to allow quick and easy interaction with a company s customers.   as humanity has evolved and progressed through the ages so have the tools we as a species use to make our lives easier  and that is what brings me to my message of great importance:  PLEASE can you change the fork you include with your pasta dishes (the ones which are included in your meal deals) to something a bit more sturdy? the poorly made utensil which is included with the food is flimsy and frankly difficult to try and eat with. the terrible hinged joint in the middle used to make the handle of the fork longer is incredibly weak and food has been spilt because of it. at times i have even considered using a pair of matchsticks and some tape to form a splint to hold the joint together because of the problems i have had with the folding fork included with the meal. this is 2016. disposable forks should not be as terrible as the ones you include in your pasta meals.  a shorter  sturdier handled fork would be much more convenient to use  even for someone with large hands such as myself. you could take a leaf out of the co-operative s book and use the humble Spork. it is a delightful tool created for easy  on-the-go consumption of meals which need a utensil which has both the prongs to hold food safely and the capacity to keep a decent amount of the meal in place as it travels from bowl/plate to mouth.   top much of your delicious pasta has been spilt down the front of people s clothes because the utensil you have provided has been inefficient at keeping food in place between plate and mouth.  i implore you  PLEASE make a change. let no more pasta be spilt because of this minor  yet horrible problem.  sincerely  Joshua Hammond.

Well i have never been so annoyed.  Just returned from tesco in Drogheda today.  I purchased my groceries and my 25year old son was next with some alcohol.  He was asked for ID but had none. The supervisor was called and her explanation wasn t much more helpful.  They couldn t sell the alcohl to me because they said i was buying it for him.  This is ridiculous.    1.  No signage at the alcohol counter about company policy.  2. Would I have have been so stupid as to let this happen had i known the policies. NO.  I just would ve told my son I would get the alcohol for him and sent him outside to wait.  He is 25 after all  3. You can purchase alcohol online and have it delivered to the home of a person who has  teenagers living with them. Does this mean you shouldn t sell alcohol on line? 4.
